title: Acts Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 17.

questions.question: Where did Paul and his companions first come to in Acts chapter 17?
questions.correctAnswer: Thessalonica
questions.explanation: Acts 17:1 states that they came to Thessalonica first.

questions.question: How many sabbath days did Paul reason with the Jews in Thessalonica?
questions.correctAnswer: Three
questions.explanation: Acts 17:2 mentions Paul reasoned for three sabbath days.

questions.question: According to Acts 17:3, what must Christ do?
options: Suffer and rise again from the dead
questions.correctAnswer: Suffer and rise again from the dead
questions.explanation: Acts 17:3 explains that Christ must suffer and rise again from the dead.

questions.question: Who were stirred with envy and caused an uproar in Thessalonica?
questions.correctAnswer: The Jews which believed not
questions.explanation: Acts 17:5 states that the unbelieving Jews, moved with envy, caused the uproar.

questions.question: Who was accused of receiving Paul and Silas and turning the world upside down?
questions.correctAnswer: Jason
questions.explanation: Acts 17:6-7 shows Jason was accused of receiving them and causing trouble.

questions.question: Where did Paul and Silas go immediately after leaving Thessalonica?
questions.correctAnswer: Berea
questions.explanation: Acts 17:10 says Paul and Silas were sent to Berea by night.

questions.question: How were the Bereans described in their reception of the word?
options: Noble and searched the scriptures daily
questions.correctAnswer: Noble and searched the scriptures daily
questions.explanation: Acts 17:11 describes the Bereans as noble and eager to verify the scriptures daily.

questions.question: Who stayed in Berea after Paul was sent away?
questions.correctAnswer: Silas and Timotheus
questions.explanation: Acts 17:14 states Silas and Timotheus remained in Berea while Paul left.

questions.question: What stirred Paul's spirit when he arrived in Athens?
questions.correctAnswer: The city's devotion to idolatry
questions.explanation: Acts 17:16 says Paul's spirit was stirred by seeing the city full of idols.

questions.question: Where did Paul preach daily while in Athens?
options: In the synagogue and the marketplace
questions.correctAnswer: In the synagogue and the marketplace
questions.explanation: Acts 17:17 states Paul disputed in the synagogue and daily in the market.

questions.question: True or False: Epicurean and Stoic philosophers mocked Paul because he preached Jesus and the resurrection.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 17:18 reveals some philosophers called Paul a babbler for preaching Jesus and resurrection.

questions.question: True or False: The Areopagus council wanted to learn about Paul's new doctrine.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 17:19-20 shows the Areopagus asked Paul to explain his teaching.

questions.question: True or False: Paul told the men of Athens that their worship of the unknown god was correct and complete.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 17:23 shows Paul said they ignorantly worship the unknown god and he declares him to them.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Acts 17:24: 'God that made the world and all things therein, dwelling not in ______ made with hands;'
questions.correctAnswer: temples
questions.explanation: Acts 17:24 says God dwelleth not in temples made with hands.

questions.question: According to Acts 17:31, what has God appointed to judge the world?
questions.correctAnswer: A day appointed
questions.explanation: Acts 17:31 explains God appointed a day to judge the world in righteousness.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Acts 17 teach us about perseverance through trials when facing opposition for our faith?
options: Paul and Silas continued preaching despite being expelled and threatened
Paul stopped preaching to avoid conflict
The believers gave up and hid from the Jews
The apostles asked the city rulers to protect them
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Silas continued preaching despite being expelled and threatened
questions.explanation: Acts 17:5-10 and Acts 17:13-15 show that despite opposition from unbelieving Jews causing uproar and threats, Paul and Silas were sent on to continue preaching in other cities, demonstrating perseverance through trials.

questions.question: What biblical principle about personal study and readiness to receive the Word is illustrated by the Bereans in Acts 17?
options: They examined the scriptures daily to verify Paul's teaching
They accepted all teachings without question
They only listened on the Sabbath
They relied solely on Paul’s authority
questions.correctAnswer: They examined the scriptures daily to verify Paul's teaching
questions.explanation: Acts 17:11 highlights that the Bereans were noble because they received the message with eagerness and examined the Scriptures daily to confirm what Paul taught, showing the importance of personal study and discernment.

questions.question: When Paul addressed the Athenians, what attitude toward God and worship did he challenge that is relevant for humility and true worship?
options: Their superstition and worship of an unknown god
Their worship of only one known God
Their worship of natural elements only
questions.correctAnswer: Their superstition and worship of an unknown god
questions.explanation: Acts 17:22-23 shows Paul confronting the Athenians’ superstition and ignorance in worshipping an unknown god, urging them to seek the true God, which teaches humility and sincerity in worship.

questions.question: According to Acts 17, how can we understand God's provision and care for all people in everyday life?
options: God gives all life, breath, and everything to all people
God requires temples to dwell among people
God needs offerings to sustain Himself
questions.correctAnswer: God gives all life, breath, and everything to all people
questions.explanation: Acts 17:24-25 explains that God, the creator who does not dwell in man-made temples, gives life and breath to all, teaching us to trust God's provision universally.

questions.question: How does Acts 17 encourage believers to view the unity and equality of all people before God?
options: God made all nations from one blood and determined their times and places
Only Jews are chosen by God
questions.correctAnswer: God made all nations from one blood and determined their times and places
questions.explanation: Acts 17:26 teaches that God created all nations from one blood and set their appointed times and boundaries, emphasizing human unity and equality under God.

questions.question: What practical lesson about seeking God is found in Paul’s message on Mars’ Hill?
options: People should seek God because He is near to each of us
questions.correctAnswer: People should seek God because He is near to each of us
questions.explanation: Acts 17:27 encourages seeking God who is not far from anyone, teaching believers to actively seek a personal relationship with Him.

questions.question: How can the truth of God’s judgment and resurrection encourage a believer facing doubt or mockery?
options: God appointed a day to judge the world with assurance through Jesus’ resurrection
Resurrection is a myth to ignore
Mockery is a sign that faith is wrong
questions.correctAnswer: God appointed a day to judge the world with assurance through Jesus’ resurrection
questions.explanation: Acts 17:31 shows God’s promise of judgment and resurrection through Jesus, providing assurance and hope to believers amidst opposition and doubt.

questions.question: How does Acts 17 demonstrate the importance of sharing the Gospel even in a culture unfamiliar or hostile to it?
options: Paul preached daily in synagogues and marketplaces despite skepticism
Paul avoided cities where people disagreed
Paul remained silent to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Paul preached daily in synagogues and marketplaces despite skepticism
questions.explanation: Acts 17:17-18 records Paul debating in synagogues and the marketplace daily, showing persistence in evangelism even when facing skepticism and hostility.

questions.question: True or False: The Jews who opposed Paul were motivated by envy and stirred up the city against him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 17:5 states the unbelieving Jews were moved with envy and caused an uproar against Paul, showing the reality of opposition believers can face.

questions.question: True or False: The Athenians eagerly accepted Paul's message without any skepticism or mocking.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 17:32 records that some mocked Paul’s message about resurrection while others were curious to hear more, illustrating mixed responses to the Gospel.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels discouraged because their faith is mocked. Based on Acts 17, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Some will mock, but God’s resurrection and judgment are sure
Mockery means your faith is wrong
You should stop sharing your faith to avoid ridicule
Faith is only for the strong and popular
questions.correctAnswer: Some will mock, but God’s resurrection and judgment are sure
questions.explanation: Acts 17:31-32 teaches that despite mockery, God’s appointed judgment through the risen Jesus is certain, encouraging believers to remain steadfast.

questions.question: How does Acts 17 show the importance of community support and fellowship in evangelism?
options: The brethren sent Paul and Silas away for safety and support
questions.correctAnswer: The brethren sent Paul and Silas away for safety and support
questions.explanation: Acts 17:10 and 17:14 show the believers supporting Paul and Silas by sending them away for safety and continuing ministry, illustrating the role of fellowship in perseverance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity in work and witness can we learn from Paul's approach in Acts 17?
options: Paul reasoned from Scriptures daily in synagogues and public places
Paul only preached in private homes
questions.correctAnswer: Paul reasoned from Scriptures daily in synagogues and public places
questions.explanation: Acts 17:2 and 17 show Paul’s consistent, open, and diligent witness both in synagogues and marketplaces, emphasizing integrity and commitment in evangelism.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Acts 17:28, 'For in him we live, and move, and have our ____, as certain also of your own poets have said, For we are also his offspring.'
questions.correctAnswer: being
questions.explanation: Acts 17:28 uses the phrase 'have our being' to express our complete dependence on God, highlighting the foundational truth of life in Him.

questions.question: How does the example of Dionysius and Damaris at the end of Acts 17 encourage believers in evangelism?
options: Some individuals respond positively and believe after hearing the Gospel
No one believed the message in Athens
questions.correctAnswer: Some individuals respond positively and believe after hearing the Gospel
questions.explanation: Acts 17:34 records that certain men and women, including Dionysius and Damaris, believed and followed Paul, encouraging believers that evangelism can bear fruit even in difficult contexts.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 17.

questions.question: What was Paul's primary method of teaching in Thessalonica according to Acts 17?
options: Reasoning from the scriptures for three sabbath days
Performing miracles to prove his point
Writing letters to the synagogue leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Reasoning from the scriptures for three sabbath days
questions.explanation: Acts 17:2 states Paul went in unto them and reasoned with them out of the scriptures for three sabbath days.

questions.question: In Acts 17, what was the main thesis Paul presented to the Jews in the synagogue?
options: That Christ must suffer and rise from the dead
That the Law of Moses is obsolete
That the temple should be destroyed
That Jesus was a prophet like Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: That Christ must suffer and rise from the dead
questions.explanation: Acts 17:3 shows Paul opening and alleging that Christ must suffer and rise again from the dead, identifying Jesus as the Christ.

questions.question: Who among the Thessalonians believed Paul's message and joined him?
options: Some Jews, devout Greeks, and chief women
questions.correctAnswer: Some Jews, devout Greeks, and chief women
questions.explanation: Acts 17:4 mentions that some Jews believed and consorted with Paul and Silas, along with a great multitude of devout Greeks and chief women.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Jews who did not believe in Thessalonica?
options: They stirred up an uproar and assaulted Jason's house
They invited Paul to debate in the marketplace
They wrote letters to the governor praising Paul
questions.correctAnswer: They stirred up an uproar and assaulted Jason's house
questions.explanation: Acts 17:5 describes that the unbelieving Jews, moved by envy, gathered a company and set the city on an uproar, assaulting Jason's house.

questions.question: What accusation was brought against Paul and his companions before the city rulers in Thessalonica?
options: They turned the world upside down and declared another king named Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: They turned the world upside down and declared another king named Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 17:6-7 records the accusation that Paul and his company had turned the world upside down and were proclaiming Jesus as another king contrary to Caesar's decrees.

questions.question: How did the believers in Berea respond to Paul's teaching compared to those in Thessalonica?
options: They received the word with readiness and searched the scriptures daily
They only listened on the sabbath day
questions.correctAnswer: They received the word with readiness and searched the scriptures daily
questions.explanation: Acts 17:11 highlights the Bereans' noble character as they received the message eagerly and examined the scriptures daily to verify Paul's teaching.

questions.question: What prompted the Jews from Thessalonica to come to Berea and cause trouble there?
options: They heard Paul was preaching the word of God in Berea
They wanted to invite Paul to a feast
They sought to learn more about the resurrection
They were sent by the Roman government
questions.correctAnswer: They heard Paul was preaching the word of God in Berea
questions.explanation: Acts 17:13 explains that when the Jews of Thessalonica learned Paul was preaching in Berea, they came there to stir up the people.

questions.question: What was Paul's reaction upon arriving in Athens as described in Acts 17?
options: His spirit was stirred because the city was full of idols
He immediately preached in the synagogue without delay
He refused to engage with the philosophers
He stayed silent and observed only
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit was stirred because the city was full of idols
questions.explanation: Acts 17:16 states Paul’s spirit was stirred when he saw Athens was wholly given to idolatry.

questions.question: Which groups did Paul debate with while in Athens?
options: Jews, devout persons, and daily market attendees
questions.correctAnswer: Jews, devout persons, and daily market attendees
questions.explanation: Acts 17:17 reveals Paul disputed in the synagogue with Jews and devout persons and also daily in the marketplace with those who met him.

questions.question: What was the reaction of some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers to Paul's teaching?
options: They called him a babbler or a proclaimer of strange gods
They arrested him on the spot
questions.correctAnswer: They called him a babbler or a proclaimer of strange gods
questions.explanation: Acts 17:18 shows that some philosophers mocked Paul calling him a babbler or saying he preached strange gods.

questions.question: Why was Paul brought to the Areopagus in Athens?
options: To explain this new doctrine he was preaching
To receive a formal invitation to stay in Athens
questions.correctAnswer: To explain this new doctrine he was preaching
questions.explanation: Acts 17:19-20 states they brought Paul to the Areopagus to learn about the new doctrine he was preaching.

questions.question: In Paul's speech at Mars' hill, how does he describe God in relation to temples made by humans?
options: God does not dwell in temples made with hands
God is pleased with temples built by men
God only dwells in the temple in Jerusalem
God is an idol made by craftsmen
questions.correctAnswer: God does not dwell in temples made with hands
questions.explanation: Acts 17:24 asserts that God, the Creator, does not live in temples made by human hands.

questions.question: According to Paul's speech in Acts 17, what is the relationship between all nations?
options: They are of one blood and God determined their times and boundaries
They are completely unrelated and unknown to God
They are free to choose any gods they want without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: They are of one blood and God determined their times and boundaries
questions.explanation: Acts 17:26 explains God made all nations from one blood and set their appointed times and boundaries.

questions.question: What does Paul urge all men everywhere to do because God has appointed a day to judge the world?
questions.correctAnswer: Repent
questions.explanation: Acts 17:30-31 states that God commands all men to repent because He will judge the world through Jesus raised from the dead.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 17, some people mocked the resurrection of the dead when Paul preached it.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 17:32 mentions that some mocked the resurrection, while others showed interest in hearing more.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What method did Paul use to persuade the Thessalonian Jews about Jesus?
options: He reasoned with them from the Scriptures for three sabbath days
He performed miracles to prove Jesus' divinity
He quoted pagan philosophers to connect with them
He taught only in the marketplace
questions.correctAnswer: He reasoned with them from the Scriptures for three sabbath days
questions.explanation: Paul, as was his custom, reasoned with the Jews in the synagogue for three sabbath days, demonstrating from the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ (Acts 17:2-3). This method aligns with Jesus' own teaching style (Luke 24:27) and Paul's approach in other letters (2 Timothy 3:16-17).

questions.question: According to Acts 17, what must Christ do according to the Scriptures?
options: Suffer and rise again from the dead
Perform miracles to prove His authority
Establish a physical kingdom on earth
questions.correctAnswer: Suffer and rise again from the dead
questions.explanation: Paul opened and alleged that Christ must suffer and rise again from the dead, fulfilling prophecy and affirming the resurrection as essential (Acts 17:3). This is consistent with Isaiah 53, Psalm 16:10, and Jesus' own predictions (Mark 8:31).

questions.question: What was the reaction of some Jews who did not believe in Thessalonica?
options: They were moved with envy and stirred up an uproar
They welcomed Paul and Silas warmly
questions.correctAnswer: They were moved with envy and stirred up an uproar
questions.explanation: The unbelieving Jews, driven by envy, gathered certain disreputable men and incited the city to riot against Paul and Silas (Acts 17:5). This mirrors opposition encountered by prophets (Jeremiah 20:8-10) and Jesus Himself (John 11:53).

questions.question: Who was accused of receiving Paul and Silas and causing turmoil in Thessalonica?
questions.correctAnswer: Jason
questions.explanation: Jason was seized and accused before the city rulers for hosting Paul and Silas and for the claim of another king, Jesus, which was seen as contrary to Caesar's decrees (Acts 17:6-7). This incident shows early Christian challenges to political authority (Daniel 7:13-14).

questions.question: How did the Berean Jews respond to Paul's message compared to those in Thessalonica?
options: They received the word with eagerness and searched the Scriptures daily
questions.correctAnswer: They received the word with eagerness and searched the Scriptures daily
questions.explanation: The Bereans were noble-minded because they examined the Scriptures daily to verify Paul's teaching, showing a diligent and discerning faith (Acts 17:11). This exemplifies the Bereans as a model of scriptural engagement (1 Thessalonians 5:21).

questions.question: What accusation did the opponents from Thessalonica bring against Paul in Berea?
options: They stirred up the people against him
questions.correctAnswer: They stirred up the people against him
questions.explanation: When the Thessalonian Jews learned Paul was preaching in Berea, they came to stir up the crowds against him, continuing the pattern of opposition to the gospel (Acts 17:13). This reflects the persistent rejection of messengers in Old Testament prophecy (Psalm 2:1-3).

questions.question: What stirred Paul's spirit when he arrived in Athens?
options: Seeing the city full of idols
Meeting with the Jewish leaders only
The political stability of the city
The beauty of the city's architecture
questions.correctAnswer: Seeing the city full of idols
questions.explanation: Paul's spirit was provoked because Athens was entirely given over to idolatry, which deeply grieved him and motivated his evangelistic efforts (Acts 17:16). This concern reflects Old Testament condemnation of idolatry (Exodus 20:3-5; Isaiah 44:9-20).

questions.question: How did the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers initially respond to Paul's preaching?
options: They called him a babbler and accused him of preaching strange gods
They immediately believed and followed him
They invited him to a royal court
questions.correctAnswer: They called him a babbler and accused him of preaching strange gods
questions.explanation: Philosophers labeled Paul a babbler and accused him of introducing strange gods because he preached Jesus and the resurrection, ideas foreign to their philosophy (Acts 17:18). This shows the challenge of Christian apologetics in a pluralistic context (1 Corinthians 1:18-25).

questions.question: What was the Areopagus' interest in Paul's teaching?
options: They wanted to understand the new doctrine he preached
They wanted to imprison him immediately
They invited him to a religious festival
questions.correctAnswer: They wanted to understand the new doctrine he preached
questions.explanation: The Areopagus asked Paul to explain his new teaching, indicating their curiosity about his message (Acts 17:19-20). This reflects an openness to philosophical discourse and the importance of apologetics (Acts 17:21).

questions.question: According to Paul's speech on Mars' hill, how is the unknown God described?
options: God made the world and does not dwell in man-made temples
God is one idol among many
God changes according to human invention
questions.correctAnswer: God made the world and does not dwell in man-made temples
questions.explanation: Paul explained that the unknown God is the Creator who made everything and does not live in temples made by human hands (Acts 17:23-24). This contrasts with pagan idolatry and aligns with Old Testament teaching about the invisible, transcendent God (Isaiah 66:1; Psalm 115:4-8).

questions.question: What does Paul say about God’s need for worship and provision?
options: God does not need anything from humans because He gives life and all things
God depends on human offerings for sustenance
God requires daily sacrifices to exist
God is silent and indifferent to worship
questions.correctAnswer: God does not need anything from humans because He gives life and all things
questions.explanation: Paul taught that God is self-sufficient, not needing human hands or worship, because He gives life and breath to all (Acts 17:25). This reflects divine aseity and sovereignty (Psalm 50:12; Isaiah 40:28).

questions.question: What theological truth does Paul present about the origin and unity of humanity?
options: God made all nations from one blood and determined their times and places
Each nation originated independently without divine purpose
Nations are random with no divine boundaries
questions.correctAnswer: God made all nations from one blood and determined their times and places
questions.explanation: Paul states God created all peoples from one blood and appointed their times and boundaries, emphasizing unity and divine sovereignty over history (Acts 17:26). This corresponds with Genesis 1-2 and the universal scope of salvation (Malachi 2:10).

questions.question: What is the purpose God has for humanity according to Paul’s Areopagus speech?
options: That they should seek God and find Him, since He is not far from any of us
That they should worship many gods
That they should remain ignorant of God
That they should live apart from God
questions.correctAnswer: That they should seek God and find Him, since He is not far from any of us
questions.explanation: Paul explains God’s intention that all seek Him and find Him because He is near to everyone (Acts 17:27). This affirms God's immanence and desire for relationship (Jeremiah 29:13; Deuteronomy 4:29).

questions.question: How does Paul describe humanity’s relationship to God in terms of existence?
options: In Him we live, move, and have our being
God is unaware of our existence
We are enemies of God by nature
questions.correctAnswer: In Him we live, move, and have our being
questions.explanation: Paul states that our life, movement, and being are sustained by God, emphasizing dependence on the Creator (Acts 17:28). This echoes Old Testament affirmations of God as the source of life (Psalm 139:13-16; Colossians 1:17).

questions.question: What commandment does God now give to all men, according to Paul?
options: To repent because He has set a day to judge the world
questions.correctAnswer: To repent because He has set a day to judge the world
questions.explanation: God commands all people everywhere to repent, since He has appointed a day of righteous judgment through Jesus, whom He raised from the dead (Acts 17:30-31). This is fundamental to Christian eschatology and salvation (Joel 2:12; 2 Corinthians 5:10).
